texts.shortText: Small, but very conspicuous and much photographed species with characteristic laterally flattened body with distinct ridge along the centre of the back and unusually short antennae with greatly reduced flagellum. There are triangular teeth on the back on each of the first three abdominal segments. Very distinctive bold colour pattern with wide yellow stripe along centre of back, sides of body purple to blue with red vertical stripes and orange legs!

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to KwaZulu-Natal.

A common species on shallow reefs, where it moves around brazenly in the open, clearly defended by its bright warning colouration, which presumably warns predators that it is distasteful. Often seen gathering on whelk shells that are covered by the nodular bryozoan Alcyonidium nodosum.

Appear to feed on the nodular bryozoan Alcyonidium nodosum, which occurs only on the shells of the whelk Burnupena papyracea. Often seen gathered in large numbers on these whelks. Exactly what chemicals are sequestered from the bryozoan and how these are involved in protecting the amphipod are unknown, but would make for a fascinating study.
As with all amphipods the eggs are released into a brood pouch between the legs of the female, where they are fertilized by males and develop into fully formed young before being released.
Fairly unmistakable, could at first glance or superficially be confused with the Hunchback amphipod Iphimedia gibba.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 96).

Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town (p. 61).
